entry.title: DE-ICE-S1.130
entry.content:
Image: De-ICE: S1.130

Nmap output:

Dirb output:

There is nothing interesting for us except the sysadmin account.

Web page mentions customerserviceadmin@nosecbank.com email address. After a little trying, we found out the user account that exists:

We use hydra to crack user account successfully (ftp was the fastest way):

We log in as csadmin / rocker:

In home directory, there is a clue how to get sdadmin’s password:

Also there is a secord part of some algorithm:

Using this information, we was able to crack the password:

We log in as sdadmin / donovin1998 and repeat the process:

So the dbadmin’s password could be related with the word databaser:

We extract the last part of the email and put everything together:

After fixing minor issues, we compile the code in Java:

We encrypt another usernames to get passwords.

Now we can log as sysadmin. Using sudo:

Because we are in wheel group, we can invoke the command ‘su’ directly to obtain the root access:

From the home directory of sysadmin user, we locate the encrypted file in ftp and use script for decryption, with the password of the root user:

entry.title: DE-ICE-S1.120
entry.content:
Image: De-ICE: S1.120

Nmap output:

Nikto output:

As we can see, Nikto reveals the installation of phpmyadmin and some minor vulnerabilities. There is an information about CVE-2002-0082 too, but we didn’t find any exploit for the issue.

We connect to the web page, add a few products and try sql injection:

We found out that it works so we try sqlmap to dump the whole database content:

This gives us the mysql sha1 hashes. After a small formating, we got:

Trying to login through ssh:

We use one of the accounts to log in and check if there is any user with the higher privileges:

Right, ccoffee is in admin group. For other users it is not allowed to use sudo.

We check his competencies:

There is a script in his home directory that he can execute, unfortunately we cannot read the content. Removing the script and creating a new one with the content ‘sh’ gives root:

We realized that the passwords are different when we reboot the server. Digging deeper, we find more clues:

Finally with this information, we was able to successfully crack the whole /etc/shadow:

There is also a trace that the root user connected via ssh to another server with IP address 192.168.1.20:

entry.title: Kioptrix: Level 2
entry.content:
Image: Kioptrix: Level 1.1 (#2)

Nmap output:

We connect to the web page and log in using username / password (SQLi):

Now we got the access to the “Basic Administrative Web Console”. Trying command injection, we found out that we can inject arbitrary command and execute under web user privileges.

Request / response example:

Web server fingerprints:

We don’t have writable access under DocumentRoot. Looking to different directories, we found the netcat source remains.

So there should be netcat installed, we will need this information later.

We can read index.php for mysql credentials:

The john’s password doesn’t work for ssh, but at least we can extract more from mysql database:

Again, the passwords don’t work for ssh.

We find netcat and use it to bind a shell, then we try to root the box:

Luckily, exploitdb contains local root exploit with exactly this version of kernel:

As our last step, we download and compile this exploit https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/9542/ .

entry.title: VulnImage: 1
entry.content:
Image: VulnImage: 1

Nmap output:

With dirb we found a few interesting directories (repo, admin, profiles), directory listing is enabled:

Submitting the quote gives an error SQL message:

After a few minutes of playing with requests we realize that we can create files in format ‘username-fname’ and with the content of ‘sig’ parameter.

Now we have a simple PHP shell:

We download the weevely.php from our server and connect:

In the repo directory, we examine the buffd.c. It is a vulnerable daemon, listening on port 7777.

We copy buffd binary from server (/usr/local/sbin/buffd) and using metasploit patterns we calculate the offset for EIP. To make an exploit reliable, we are looking also for some registers, pointing to our pattern in memory.

EIP begins on offset 124 and the register EAX points to the beginning of our buffer, right now filled with pattern. Luckily, we find call eax opcodes in binary too.

The strange thing is that the stack in binary is marked as non-executable, but on this server the exploit works and we don’t get segfault:

Exploit in Ruby:

Exploit runs arbitrary command that we put on vulnerable server to /tmp/commands.

We connect to the host:

To obtain root privileges, we can run ssh server and put to ‘/tmp/commands’ file the instructions to change root password:

Kernel is vulnerable too, using this exploit we can get uid 0 privileges:

In Metasploit is there is another module which we can use to exploit Exim4 (exploit/unix/smtp/exim4_string_format). To make it work correctly, we need to comment the following lines and also change exim to exim4:

entry.title: Holynix: V2
entry.content:
Image: Holynix: v2

We set our network preferences to “Share with my Mac” on both vulnerable server and Kali Linux. Our NIC address will be the following:

Nmap output for 192.168.1.88:

We add to /etc/hosts:

Asking DNS server about the domain reports:

We append these lines to /etc/hosts and try DNS AXFR (zone transfer):

We change our IP address to the IP of the not reachable DNS server and try AXFR again:

Appending the list to /etc/hosts:

Dirb reports the following URLs:

In particular the interesting file was http://www.zincftp.com/setup_guides/todo

Again we set our IP address to match the “trusted.zincftp.com” host, to get access to phpmyadmin:

We found nothing interesting in phpmyadmin, but it’s vulnerable and we can interpret the arbitrary file on web server as PHP script.

We can also try to perform the brute-force attack on ftp users (see /etc/group) and generate the short wordlist with john according username, but without success, ftp connection is limited with the firewall:

After a while we found the hash list for ftp and used the john to crack it:

We uploaded weevely to web directory of tmartin user via ftp:

The kernel was vulnerable (vmsplice, 5092.c) and because weevely shell always logged out root user, we used reverse shell and the writable /dev/shm directory.

On our Kali Linux:

We also found:

If there is not a vulnerable phpmyadmin, we can read the files to table too, according:

1) zincftp_data -> Create new table on database zincftp_data

2) Name = ftp_pass, Number of fields = 1

3) Field = pass, Type = varchar, Length = 100
